multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have skin depressions on my arms and legs that have been there for a few months.
Do these skin depressions have any redness, tenderness, or discharge?
No, the lesions are not painful, itchy, or showing any redness or discharge.
When did you first notice these skin depressions and have they changed over time?
I first noticed these skin depressions a few months ago, and there hasn't been any mention of them changing over time.
Have you had any recent illnesses, infections, or significant weight loss?
No, there have been no recent illnesses, infections, or significant weight loss reported.
Have you been using any new medications or topical treatments before noticing these skin depressions?
No, there have been no new medications or treatments used before noticing these skin depressions.
Do you have any current or past medical conditions that could be related to this issue?
My past medical history includes being born with red skin across my entire body and thin flaky yellow skin on my back and chest, which slowly healed.
Do these skin depressions resemble stretch marks or do they have a different appearance?
They have a different appearance, more like multiple follicular-based depressions in a curvilinear distribution on the hands, legs, and feet.
Final Diagnosis: Lipoatrophy
